question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

Find the area of the region enclosed by one loop of the polar curve
$r=4\cos (2\theta).$
sols:
We can consider one loop of the polar curve to be defined by the values
of $\theta$ in between successive points where $r = 0$. Consider that
$\cos(z) = 0$, where $z = -\pi/2$ and $\pi/2$, so we can take $\theta$
to be vary in between $\theta = -\pi/4$ and $\pi / 4$ to define a loop.

Now consider that the area of a wedge with angle $\Delta \theta$ is
equal to $r^{2}\Delta \theta/2$ where $r$ is the'radius' of the wedge
(i.e: from the point to the rounded boundary). To compute the total area
of the loop we simply integrate in between the appropriate angles.

\begin{align*}
A &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\frac{1}{2}r(\theta)^{2}\,d\theta \\
&= 8\int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\cos^{2}(2\theta)\,d\theta
\end{align*}

Using a trigonometric identity, we can simplify this integral so we are
not dealing with the square of a trig function.

\begin{align*}
A &= 8\int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\cos^{2}(2\theta)\,d\theta \\
& = 4\int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}1 + \cos(4\theta)\,d\theta \\
& = 2\pi
\end{align*}

Therefore, the area of one loop of the polar curve $r = 4\cos(2\theta)$
is $2\pi$.
